docs.lead_paragraph: The perks at Google have long been the talk of Silicon Valley and beyond. But when all is said and done, how do they stack up against the perks at Microsoft? And which is the better workplace?

headline.main: Google v. Microsoft: What's the Better Workplace?

docs.abstract: Circulating online, the thoughts of an employee who's worked at both places, comparing the offices, pay and perks.
docs.snippet: Circulating online, the thoughts of an employee who's worked at both places, comparing the offices, pay and perks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

headline.main: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon

docs.abstract: Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat. Mr. Slim's companies dominate Mexico's telecommunications industry, and they have sold cellphones to 130 million people throughout the Americas. His businesses have a [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students complete a survey on hot topics in the 2008 presidential campaign. They then each investigate one featured topic in detail and write a concise summary in preparation for writing a letter to the editor that responds to the article.

byline.original: By JENNIFER RITTNER and JAVAID KHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of the Democratic primary presidential debate on PBS. The participants were Senator Joseph Biden, Jr. (D-Del.); Senator Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.); Senator Christopher Dodd (D-Conn.); Former Senator John Edwards (D-S.C.); Former Senator Mike Gravel (D-Ak); Representative Dennis Kucinich (D-Ohio); Senator Barack Obama (D-Ill.); and Gov. Bill Richardson (D-N.M.). The moderator was Tavis Smiley, host of “Tavis Smiley” on PBS. The panelists were Michel Martin, journalist and NPR host; Ruben Navarrette, Jr., nationally syndicated columnist; Dewayne Wickham, USA Today and Gannett News Service columnist. The debate took place at Howard University on Thursday, June 28, 2007. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline.main: Transcript of the Third Democratic Primary Presidential Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about government ratings for hospitals misstated the number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die. The report lists 41 hospitals, not 42, whose death rates are worse than the national average, and 52 hospitals, not 55, whose deaths rates are better than average. A list of the hospitals can be found at www.nytimes.com/health.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 22 article about government ratings for hospitals, regarding number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll asked young voters about their political views and their opinion, so far, of the candidates and key issues in the 2008 election. The nationwide telephone poll was conducted June 15-23 with 659 young adults ages 17-29. Here are follow-up interviews with some of the respondents.

A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the program’s organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.
